translator_notes: This page completes the table of contents with chapters 75-80 and appendices
「河东狮」(Shrew from the East/Lion's Roar from the East of the River) is a classical Chinese idiom for a domineering wife, originating from a story about the poet Su Shi's friend
「中山狼」(Wolf of Zhongshan) refers to an ungrateful person who turns on their benefactor, from the fable 'The Wolf of Zhongshan'
「芙蓉诔」(Hibiscus Elegy) in Chapter 78 is Baoyu's elegy for the deceased Qingwen, one of the most moving passages in the novel
The 脂评汇校本 contains only 80 chapters - this is the authentic Cao Xueqin text, unlike the 120-chapter Cheng-Gao edition
「靖藏本」(Jing Collection Manuscript) is a lost but important manuscript, known only through Mao Guoyao's transcriptions
research_notes: Chapter 77 contains the tragic death of Qingwen, one of the most beloved maid characters
Chapter 78's Hibiscus Elegy is considered one of the finest pieces of elegiac prose in Chinese literature
The appendices provide valuable scholarly material on manuscript traditions and textual criticism
